title: My first post
contents: This is a data and statistics blog created using R.

title: My Second Post
contents:
Distill is a publication format for scientific and technical writing,
native to the web.
Learn more about using Distill at https://rstudio.github.io/distill.

title: What's up with homeruns?
description: How have home run rates changed over time?
contents:
How have home run rates changed? Are there more homeruns now than
ever?
In order to look at baseball data in R, we need a good baseball
database. Luckily one exists for R already - the Lahman
dataset. In fact, there’s even an R package available for it thanks
to Chris Dalzell and his
team. Let’s use this dataset to figure out if homerun rates are high
now compared to historical data. First, what’s the average rate of home
runs per plate appearance over time? Checking the data…



It looks like the rate increases over time, but it’s noisy data.
Let’s check if the time series is stationary. We can use the Augmented
Dickey-Fuller test from the tseries
package.


    Augmented Dickey-Fuller Test

data:  .
Dickey-Fuller = -2.71, Lag order = 4, p-value = 0.287
alternative hypothesis: stationary

Based on this results (p-value > 0.05), we can conclude that there
is a trend, and home run rates have been increasing overall in the past
70 years or so.
